snippet.title: Drenching tipped for Cairns
snippet.content: CLEAR blue skies are set to disappear with a drenching predicted in the Far North for the next three days. The Bureau of Meteorology is forecasting a trough in the upper atmosphere to drop almost 40mm in Cairns between Friday and Sunday. Cassowary Coast residents can expect heavy falls with 83mm in Innisfail and 72mm in Tully. The drought-declared Tablelands will also cop a 32mm downpour in Mareeba and 42mm in Atherton. Bureau of Meteorology forecaster Julian de Morton said the system would impact large swathes of north Queensland from the peninsula to the Capricornia district. The bulk of the system is expected to concentrate over the Townsville area. The upper trough, considered a major driver of weather, means there is an 80 per cent chance of rain in Cairns on Saturday and Sunday. The trough is coming in from western Queensland and will combine with increased moisture from the coast to produce rain. Mr de Morton said the forecast amount of rain could change. "There could be more, there could be less," he said. RAIN FORECAST Friday: 3mm Saturday: 15mm Sunday: 20mm
